title-group.article-title: An Osteochondral Lesion in the Distal Fibula
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report

contrib-group.aff: Trauma and Orthopaedic Department, Huddersfield Royal Infirmary, Huddersfield, UK

author-notes.corresp: Osman Riaz, MBChB, Trauma and Orthopaedic Department, Huddersfield Royal Infirmary, Acre Street, Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, HD3 3EA, UK; e-mail: osmanriaz@doctors.org.uk.

abstract.p: Osteochondral lesions of the talus are well-recognized clinical entities; however, this report illustrates a rare case of an osteochondral defect in the distal fibula. A 15-year-old male was referred to the orthopaedic services with a 9-month history of persistent ankle pain following an initial inversion injury. Plain X-ray was unremarkable but magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography revealed an osteochondral lesion at the level of the fibular physeal scar. The patient underwent an ankle arthroscopy where an unstable chondral flap was debrided and the associated fissure decompressed. The patient made an uneventful recovery and returned to normal sporting activities, symptom free. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with chronic ankle pain particularly with a history of an inversion injury. The purpose of this report is to raise awareness of this condition.
Levels of Evidence: Therapeutic, Level IV, Case study

disp-quote.p: “Osteochondral defects are a pathological process in which there is a fissure in the articular cartilage with extension deep into the subchondral bone.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In 1856, Monro1(p236) first described the presence of cartilaginous bodies and in 1888, König2 used the term osteochondritis dissecans for loose body formation associated with articular cartilage and a subchondral bone fragment. It was not until 1992 that the first case report of osteochondritis dissecans in the ankle was published.3

Osteochondral defects are a pathological process in which there is a fissure in the articular cartilage with extension deep into the subchondral bone.4 Most are thought to have a traumatic origin; however, there are other causes including defects of ossification, repetitive mechanical stress, and ischemia. These lesions most commonly affect the femoral condyle but can also affect the elbow, talar dome, and less frequently, the patella, vertebrae, femoral head, and the glenoid of the scapula.5

This a relatively rare disorder with incidences of 15 to 30 cases per 100 000 persons per year.6 However, an osteochondral defect is an important differential for joint pain especially in active adolescents. Often this diagnosis is overlooked as clinical signs may be limited, and the lesions may not be readily apparent on x-ray.
There are no reported cases in the literature of osteochondral defects affecting the distal fibula.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 15-year-old male was referred to the orthopaedic service with a 9-month history of ankle pain. He initially sustained an inversion injury playing rugby and attended the emergency department with anterolateral pain and swelling. Clinical examination revealed lateral malleolar tenderness with significant swelling and moderate ecchymosis around this area. X-rays were normal (Figures 1 and 2) and he was discharged with advice on how to manage his suspected lateral ligament complex ankle injury. He was provided with crutches as he was unable to bear weight for 4 days and he was then mobilizing by partial weight-bearing for a week.

Despite resting for 6 weeks he was unable to return to sporting activities and struggled for many months with persistent symptoms of anterolateral ankle pain. When seen in the orthopaedic outpatient department, his examination was essentially normal except for tenderness in the lateral talofibula articulation. There was no evidence of ankle instability or impingement signs. Foot and ankle movements were preserved. In view of his debilitating symptoms an magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was organized.

Magnetic resonance image showed a zone of bone edema centered on the subchondral physis of the medial distal fibular (Figures 3 and 4). This surrounded a well-defined 1-cm diameter focus of high signal, which itself contained a 0.6-cm sclerotic focus. This was not appreciated on the recent plain X-rays.

caption.p: Coronal T2-weighted magnetic resonance image: Left ankle.
Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance image: Left ankle.

sec.p: A differential diagnosis including an osteoid osteoma was raised given the atypical location of the lesion. Therefore, a computed tomography scan was performed to further characterize this lesion (Figures 5 and 6). This confirmed an osteochondral defect at the level of the fibular physeal scar.

caption.p: Coronal computed tomography scan: Left ankle.
Axial computed tomography scan: Left ankle.

sec.p: The patient subsequently underwent an examination under anesthesia and ankle arthroscopy where the osteochondral lesion was identified and probed. The unstable chondral flap was debrided, loose components removed, and the fissure decompressed (Figures 7 and 8).

caption.p: Intraoperative arthroscopy image demonstrating a fissure in the fibular articulation.
Fissure probed and decompressed after the chondral flap has been debrided.

sec.p: The patient made an uneventful recovery and after a short period of rehabilitation was able to return to full sporting activities. The patient was routinely followed up for a period of 14 months and he remained symptom free.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: With better clinical awareness and improved diagnostic techniques, the incidence of osteochondral defects is increasing.7 Most lesions are found on the posteromedial (58%) or anterolateral (42%) part of the talar dome. In a large MRI survey of 428 affected taluses, 53% of the lesions were localized centromedially and 26% centrolaterally.8 Of these patients, 4% to 7% have bilateral lesions, which may reflect a nontraumatic etiology.
Numerous surgical techniques for symptomatic osteochondral defects have been reported. They are generally based on these following 3 principles:

list-item.p: Debridement and bone marrow stimulation by microfracturing, drilling, and abrasion arthroplasty with or without removal of loose body
Securing a lesion to the talar dome, by transarticular fixation or retrograde drilling and cancellous bone grafting
Replacing or developing hyaline cartilage by autograft transfer, autologous chondrocyte implantation, or allografts.

sec.p: Arthroscopic debridement and bone marrow stimulation are the most commonly performed procedure for osteochondral defects.

In 2005, an expert consensus on the treatment of osteochondral defects was reached, with the group agreeing that debridement and bone marrow stimulation should be the first step in the treatment of most symptomatic defects (ISAKOS-FIMS).9 For failed primary treatment, they recommended considering osteochondral autograft transfer.

After conventional treatment for acute ankle sprains, residual symptoms are reported in 33% of patients. In these cases, patients merit further evaluation to assess for other causes for the symptoms. In the presence of normal radiographs, further imaging should be obtained and the possibility of an osteochondral defect should be considered.
